Literary Excerpt from Walter Scott

Walter Scott

Section: Item Display

There are those to whom a sense of religion has come in storm and tempest: there
are those whom it has summoned amid scenes of revelry and idle vanity: there are
those, too, who have heard its ‘still small voice’ amid rural leisure and placid
contentment; but perhaps the knowledge which causeth not to err, is most
frequently impressed upon the mind during seasons of affliction; and tears are
the softened showers which cause the seed of heaven to spring and take root in
the human breast.—
Walter Scott

Section: Featured Content

Above: Mary Avenal and Mysie Happer, from The Monastery

Commentary

This excerpt is still included in online quote data bases today. It encapsulates a Romantically-tinged understanding of spiritual individuality. It can be found in Walter Scott, The Monastery, in Three Volumes, Vol. III (Edinburgh: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown, 1820), p. 137.

Transcription
There are those to whom a sense of religion has come in storm and tempest: there
are those whom it has summoned amid scenes of revelry and idle vanity: there are
those, too, who have heard its ‘still small voice’ amid rural leisure and placid
contentment; but perhaps the knowledge which causeth not to err, is most
frequently impressed upon the mind during seasons of affliction; and tears are
the softened showers which cause the seed of heaven to spring and take root in
the human breast.—
Walter Scott
Commentary
This excerpt is still included in online quote data bases today. It encapsulates a Romantically-tinged understanding of spiritual individuality. It can be found in Walter Scott, The Monastery, in Three Volumes, Vol. III (Edinburgh: Longman, Hurst, Rees, Orme, and Brown, 1820), p. 137.
